Embolism — Simple, Exam-Oriented Explanation

( q: tiss-phys-q1 tiss-phys-q2 )

Definition:
Embolism is the sudden blockage of a blood vessel by a material (embolus) that has traveled from another part of the body through the bloodstream. This obstructs blood flow, which may cause tissue ischemia and infarction (death of tissue).

Types of Embolism (Based on the Embolus):

  1. Thromboembolism (Most common):

    • Caused by dislodged blood clot (thrombus).
    • Example: Pulmonary embolism (PE) from deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

  2. Fat embolism:

    • After long bone fractures (like femur) or trauma.
    • Fat from bone marrow enters the bloodstream.

  3. Air embolism:

    • From trauma to neck veins, improper IV line handling, or diving (decompression sickness).

  4. Amniotic fluid embolism:

    • Rare, during labor or delivery, amniotic fluid enters maternal circulation.

  5. Septic embolism:

    • Embolus contains infectious organisms (e.g., infective endocarditis vegetations).

  6. Tumor embolism:

    • Pieces of tumor enter circulation and block vessels.

Pathophysiology (General Mechanism):

  • Embolus travels via bloodstream → reaches a vessel too small to pass through → causes occlusion → ischemia of tissue downstream.
  • May lead to infarction (if severe or prolonged blockage).

Common Sites & Effects:

Type of Embolism Origin Effect / Site of Occlusion
Pulmonary embolism (PE) DVT (usually leg veins) Pulmonary arteries → lung infarction, hypoxia
Systemic (arterial) embolism Heart (e.g., atrial fibrillation, MI) Brain (stroke), kidneys, limbs
Fat embolism Fractured long bones Lungs (respiratory distress), brain (neurological symptoms)
Air embolism IV line, trauma, diving Heart, brain, lungs (depends on entry)
Amniotic fluid embolism Uterus during labor Lungs, systemic (severe reaction, DIC)

Clinical Features (Depending on Site):

  • Pulmonary embolism (PE):

    • Sudden dyspnea, chest pain, tachypnea, hemoptysis (if infarction), tachycardia.

  • Systemic embolism (Stroke):

    • Sudden weakness, paralysis, speech disturbances.

  • Fat embolism syndrome:

    • Respiratory distress, petechial rash, neurological symptoms (confusion, coma).

  • Air embolism:

    • Chest pain, dyspnea, neurological signs, circulatory collapse (if massive).

  • Amniotic fluid embolism:

    • Sudden cardiovascular collapse, DIC, severe respiratory distress during/after labor.

Diagnosis:

  • Pulmonary embolism: CT Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA), D-dimer (screening), Doppler ultrasound for DVT.
  • Fat embolism: Clinical triad (Respiratory distress + Neurological signs + Petechial rash).
  • Air embolism: Clinical context (trauma, IV), sometimes echocardiography.
  • Amniotic fluid embolism: Clinical diagnosis, sudden maternal collapse.

Treatment:

  • Pulmonary embolism: Anticoagulants (Heparin, Warfarin), thrombolytics in severe cases, surgical embolectomy if needed.
  • Systemic embolism: Address source (e.g., anticoagulate for atrial fibrillation), remove embolus if possible.
  • Fat embolism: Supportive (oxygen, fluids), corticosteroids (controversial).
  • Air embolism: Trendelenburg position, high-flow oxygen, hyperbaric oxygen in severe cases.
  • Amniotic fluid embolism: Supportive (ICU care, oxygen, blood products for DIC).

Key Points to Remember:

  • Embolism = traveling material causing sudden vessel blockage.
  • Most common embolus = thrombus (blood clot).
  • Pulmonary embolism is the most common and life-threatening type.
  • Fat embolism follows long bone fractures.
  • Air embolism is associated with trauma, IV mishandling, diving accidents.
  • Amniotic fluid embolism is rare but often fatal during childbirth.
  • Treatment usually involves anticoagulation, supportive care, and urgent intervention in massive embolism.
